titleStmt.title: Development of a Structural Equation Model for Sustainable Construction Practices in Nigeria

analytic.title: Development of a Structural Equation Model for Sustainable Construction Practices in Nigeria

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This study investigates the determinants of sustainable construction practices in Nigeria, focusing on the environmental, social, and economic dimensions of sustainability. Using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM), the research examines the relationships between various independent latent constructs-organizational culture, government policies, financial implications, stakeholder processes, and technology availability-and their impact on sustainability outcomes. A survey questionnaire was used to collect data from 248 respondents from 10 sampled construction companies in Nigeria. The data collected was analysed using SIMPLEX Project in LISREL The result of the SEM highlight the paramount importance of government policies, exhibiting the highest path coefficients across all sustainability dimensions. Organizational culture significantly influences sustainability, with companies prioritizing sustainability more likely to adopt green technologies and eco-friendly practices. Financial resources, effective stakeholder engagement, and access to advanced technologies also positively impact sustainability outcomes. The study reveals significant cross-impacts among the three sustainability dimensions, demonstrating their interconnected nature. These insights provide valuable recommendations for policymakers and industry stakeholders to foster a sustainability-oriented culture, invest in technology, and engage stakeholders effectively.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The construction industry is a cornerstone of the Nigerian economy, accounting for approximately 4% of the nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and employing a substantial portion of the workforce (National Bureau of Statistics, 2020). This sector not only stimulates economic growth through infrastructure development but also serves as a catalyst for the advancement of other sectors, such as manufacturing and services. Despite its critical role in economic development, the construction it is plagued by sustainability challenges that threaten its long-term viability. One of the primary issues is the inefficient use of resources, characterized by the excessive consumption of materials and energy, which not only increases costs but also environmental impacts (Adeyeye et al., 2017). Furthermore, the industry generates a significant amount of waste, much of which is not recycled or reused, leading to increased environmental pollution and landfill use (Oluwakiyesi, 2019).

Environmental degradation associated with construction activities includes deforestation, soil erosion, and air and water pollution, which pose severe risks to public health and biodiversity (Emodi, & Boo, 2018). These environmental issues are compounded by a lack of stringent regulatory enforcement and the prevalent use of outdated and inefficient construction practices and technologies. The coexistence of these challenges with the sector's importance to the Nigerian economy highlights an urgent need for sustainable construction practices. Such practices would not only mitigate the negative environmental impacts but also enhance resource efficiency and reduce waste. There is a pressing need to adopt innovative and sustainable construction methodologies that align with global best practices while considering the local economic, social, and environmental context of Nigeria (Johnson & Turner, 2021). Sustainable construction practices in Nigeria remain nascent, facing significant obstacles that impede widespread adoption. Primary among these is a pervasive lack of awareness regarding the environmental, economic, and social benefits of sustainable construction. This issue is worsened by a scarcity of targeted educational programs and insufficient engagement with key industry stakeholders, which are crucial for fostering a culture of sustainability within the construction sector (Olawumi, & Chan, 2018).

Additionally, the regulatory frameworks necessary to support sustainable construction are underdeveloped. Current policies do not adequately incentivize the adoption of green technologies nor enforce sustainability standards in building designs and materials. This regulatory gap fails to compel or encourage construction firms to alter established practices that are often detrimental to the environment (Ezekiel & Ogunsemi, 2020). Another critical barrier is the limited access to sustainable materials and technologies. While global advancements in construction technology offer promising solutions for sustainability, these innovations are seldom integrated into the Nigerian construction industry due to high costs, limited local availability, and a lack of technical expertise necessary for implementation (Adegbile, 2021). The disparity between the recognized benefits of sustainable construction-such as reduced environmental impact, enhanced building efficiency, and improved occupant health-and its current limited application in Nigeria underscores the urgent need for a model that effectively integrates sustainable practices into the sector. Such a model would address these systemic barriers by providing a structured approach to implement sustainable practices, adapting to local challenges and leveraging available resources for maximum impact.

The primary objective of this study is to develop an empirically validated model that explains the determinants of sustainable construction practices in Nigeria. This involves identifying and analyzing the key factors that influence environmental, social, and economic sustainability in the construction sector. Specifically, the study seeks to identify and measure the key determinants that influence sustainability in construction projects, which include organizational culture, government policies and regulations, financial implications, stakeholder processes, and the availability of technology and expertise. By employing SEM, the study aims to examine the complex interrelationships among these determinants, understanding how they interact with each other and collectively influence sustainability outcomes. The study hypothesizes that these relationships are not merely linear but involve reciprocal and feedback mechanisms that reflect the dynamic nature of the construction industry.

A major focus of the study is assessing the impact of government policies and regulations on sustainability outcomes, quantifying the extent to which supportive policies enhance environmental, social, and economic sustainability in construction projects. Additionally, the study examines how organizational culture, including values, norms, and practices oriented towards sustainability, impacts the adoption and implementation of sustainable construction practices. It seeks to determine whether a strong organizational culture oriented towards sustainability leads to better sustainability outcomes. Financial considerations are another crucial aspect analyzed in the study. The study aims to understand how financial implications, such as the availability of funding for sustainable initiatives and the cost implications of sustainable practices, affect sustainability outcomes in construction projects. Furthermore, the study investigates the role of stakeholder processes, examining how stakeholder engagement, communication, and collaboration influence sustainability outcomes.

The study also explores the availability and impact of technology and expertise in promoting sustainable construction practices. It assesses how the availability and utilization of advanced technologies and the expertise of the workforce contribute to environmental, social, and economic sustainability. Ultimately, the goal is to develop a comprehensive and empirically validated model that captures the complex interactions among the various determinants of sustainability in the construction industry. This model will provide valuable insights for policymakers, industry stakeholders, and researchers. The findings of this study will have significant implications for both theory and practice. The development of a validated model will contribute to the academic literature by providing a deeper understanding of the determinants of sustainability in the construction industry. For practitioners, the insights gained from this study will inform the development of strategies and policies aimed at promoting sustainable construction practices. Policymakers will benefit from understanding the critical role of regulatory frameworks and the need for supportive policies to enhance sustainability outcomes.

div.head: Current Practices in the Nigerian Construction Industry
div.p: The construction sector in Nigeria has experienced significant growth due to rapid urbanization and economic development. Despite this growth, the industry's adoption of sustainable construction practices has been notably slow, primarily driven by a traditional focus on immediate economic returns rather than long-term sustainability goals. This emphasis on short-term gains often results in the extensive use of conventional construction materials and methods that are heavily reliant on energy consumption and resource depletion. Such practices have increase the environmental footprint of the construction sector, manifesting in increased greenhouse gas emissions, significant waste production, and widespread ecological disturbances (Bankoleet al., 2017). Environmental degradation linked to construction activities not only compromises ecological health but also affects the social fabric and economic stability of communities. For instance, the improper disposal of construction waste contributes to land pollution and can obstruct natural waterways, leading to increased flooding and associated social and economic disruptions (Olawuniet al., 2018).

In response to these challenges, there are emerging shifts toward more sustainable practices within the Nigerian construction industry. Innovations include the utilization of locally sourced materials, which reduces the carbon footprint associated with the transportation of materials. Additionally, there is an increasing interest in recycling construction waste to produce new building materials. Projects such as the use of crushed concrete as an aggregate in new construction or the repurposing of reclaimed wood and metal are examples of such initiatives (Dada., 2018). Despite these advancements, the widespread adoption of these sustainable practices remains limited. The barriers to broader implementation include a lack of standardized regulations promoting sustainable construction, insufficient knowledge and expertise among local builders and contractors about sustainable practices, and the higher upfront costs associated with green building technologies (Afolabi et al., 2019). Furthermore, there is a cultural aspect to consider, as the inertia of traditional building practices and resistance to change among local stakeholders can impede the integration of innovative, sustainable methods (Ezekiel et al., 2020).

div.head: Theoretical Framework
div.p: Developed by John Elkington in 1997, the Triple Bottom Line (TBL) theory advocates for businesses, including those in the construction industry, to commit equally to environmental, social, and economic responsibilities (Elkington, 1997). This framework emphasizes that sustainable development should balance ecological preservation with economic benefits and social well-being. In the construction sector, this means projects should minimize environmental impacts, contribute positively to the communities they affect, and still achieve economic viability. Applying the TBL theory in Nigeria is crucial as the country faces significant sustainability challenges, such as resource depletion, waste management issues, and social inequality. These challenges call for a multidimensional approach to sustainability that can be systematically addressed through the TBL framework (Ihuah et al., 2014).

Everett Rogers' Diffusion of Innovations theory, first published in 1962 and refined over subsequent editions, provides insights into how new ideas and technologies gain traction and are adopted within a society (Rogers, 2003). This theory identifies key elements that influence the adoption of new technologies: relative advantage, compatibility, complexity, trialability, and observability. In the context of Nigerian construction, these elements can explain the varying levels of acceptance and implementation of sustainable practices. For example, sustainable technologies often come with higher upfront costs and may not align with existing construction practices, posing significant barriers to their widespread adoption. Furthermore, the benefits of such technologies, while significant in the long term, may not be immediately apparent to stakeholders, thus slowing their adoption rate (Oladinrin et al., 2017). In order to effectively promote sustainable construction in Nigeria, an integrated approach that combines the TBL framework with the principles of the Diffusion of Innovations is necessary. This approach would not only advocate for the environmental, economic, and social benefits of sustainable practices but also address the practical concerns related to their adoption. For example, by demonstrating the long-term economic benefits and enhanced community wellbeing associated with sustainable construction, industry leaders can increase the relative advantage and compatibility perceptions among stakeholders. Educational and pilot programs can also be employed to enhance the trialability and observability of these practices, making them more tangible and desirable within the local context (Akanbi et al., 2019).

div.head: Gaps in Practice
div.p: The transition towards sustainable construction in Nigeria, despite the theoretical availability of advanced technologies and methods, is impeded by a constellation of barriers. These impediments are multifaceted, encompassing educational, economic, and policy-related challenges that together stifle the adoption of green building practices.

A fundamental barrier is the pervasive lack of awareness and knowledge among construction professionals and stakeholders regarding sustainable construction practices. This deficiency not only affects the adoption of existing technologies but also dampens the demand for further innovation and investment in this sector (Adeleke et al., 2019). The gap in knowledge is exacerbated by a disconnect between the capabilities of sustainable technologies and the skill sets available among local professionals, indicating a critical need for extensive training and education (Olatunji, 2021). Another significant obstacle is the inadequate support and incentives from the government. Policies that could promote sustainable construction through subsidies, tax breaks, or mandates are either underdeveloped or poorly implemented. This lack of robust governmental frameworks not only slows the adoption rates of green practices but also contributes to a business environment that favors conventional methods due to their lower upfront costs (Chendo & Obi, 2021).

The economic implications of adopting sustainable construction are also daunting. The high initial costs associated with green buildings-stemming from the premium on sustainable materials and the technologies required to deploy them-discourage widespread adoption. This financial burden can be particularly prohibitive in a developing economy where cost considerations often override environmental concerns (Lawal et al., 2022). Perhaps most critically, there is a significant gap in the integration of sustainable construction practices within the academic curriculum of Nigerian universities. The majority of construction-related programs do not adequately address sustainable construction, resulting in a workforce that is ill-prepared to meet the challenges of modern, environmentally-conscious building practices (Fagbenleet al., 2020). This educational shortfall perpetuates a cycle of non-sustainable construction practices, as new generations of construction professionals are not equipped with the necessary knowledge and skills to implement sustainable solutions effectively. Additionally, cultural and social factors play a role in the slow adoption of sustainable practices. There is often a resistance to change and a preference for traditional construction methods that are perceived as less risky and more straightforward to manage. Overcoming these cultural barriers requires not only educational interventions but also broad-based campaigns to shift public perceptions and values toward sustainability (Nduka et al., 2019).

div.head: Structural Equation Model (SEM)
div.p: Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) is a robust statistical technique used for testing and estimating causal relationships using a combination of statistical data and qualitative causal assumptions. SEM has become an indispensable tool in social sciences, behavioral sciences, education, and business research due to its ability to model complex relationships between observed and latent variables. Key concepts in SEM include latent variables, observed variables, the measurement model, the structural model, and path diagrams. Latent variables are unobserved variables inferred from observed variables and often represent abstract concepts like intelligence, satisfaction, or socioeconomic status. Observed variables are directly measured and serve as indicators for latent variables. The measurement model specifies how latent variables are measured by the observed variables, typically through confirmatory factor analysis (CFA). The structural model depicts the relationships between latent variables, including direct and indirect effects. Path diagrams are graphical representations of SEM models, illustrating the relationships between variables with arrows (Bollen, 1989;Kline, 2015).

Model specification and identification are critical steps in SEM. Specifying an SEM model involves defining the hypothesized relationships among variables based on theoretical considerations. Identification ensures that the model has a unique solution, meaning it has more known information (data points) than unknowns (parameters) to be estimated. An identified model is necessary for reliable parameter estimation and meaningful interpretation of results (Schumacker & Lomax, 2016). Several estimation methods are employed in SEM, each with its advantages and limitations. Maximum Likelihood (ML) is the most common method, assuming multivariate normality of the data. Despite its popularity, ML can be sensitive to violations of normality assumptions. Generalized Least Squares (GLS) is less sensitive to these violations, making it a suitable alternative in some cases. Bayesian Estimation, which incorporates prior distributions, is particularly useful for small sample sizes or non-normal data, offering a flexible approach to parameter estimation (Hu & Bentler, 1999;Lee, 2007).

Evaluating model fit is an essential aspect of SEM, and several indices are used for this purpose. The Chi-Square Test evaluates overall model fit but is highly sensitive to sample size, often leading to significant results even for well-fitting models. The Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) is another widely used index, with values below 0.06 indicating a good fit. The Comparative Fit Index (CFI) and Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI) are also popular, with values above 0.95 suggesting a good fit. These indices provide researchers with a comprehensive assessment of how well their model represents the data (Bentler, 1990;Steiger, 1990). SEM's applications are diverse, spanning multiple disciplines. In psychology, SEM is used to examine the relationship between mental health constructs, allowing researchers to test complex theoretical models involving multiple latent variables. In education, SEM helps assess the impact of teaching methods on student performance, providing insights into the effectiveness of different educational interventions. In marketing, SEM models consumer behavior and brand loyalty, helping businesses understand the factors that drive customer satisfaction and retention (Hoyle, 1995;Byrne, 2013;Hair et al., 2010).

Despite its strengths, SEM is not without challenges and criticisms. The complexity of SEM requires substantial statistical expertise and familiarity with specialized software like AMOS, LISREL, or Mplus. Large sample sizes are often needed for reliable estimates, which can be a limitation in studies with smaller populations. Model specification is another critical issue; misspecification can lead to incorrect conclusions, highlighting the importance of theoretical grounding and careful model development (MacCallum & Austin, 2000).

div.head: Sustainable Construction Practices
div.p: Adeleke et al. ( 2019) conducted a comprehensive study to identify the barriers hindering the adoption of green building practices in Nigeria. Employing a qualitative research approach, they gathered and analyzed the perspectives of various construction industry professionals.

The study highlighted significant barriers such as a lack of awareness, inadequate skills, and insufficient governmental incentives. The findings emphasize the need for enhanced educational programs and policy reforms to support sustainable practices. Dada (2018) focused on the use of recycled materials in Nigerian construction, aiming to promote sustainability in the sector. Through a qualitative analysis of case studies and existing literature, Dada identified that recycled materials could considerably reduce the environmental footprint of construction activities. The study concluded that integrating such materials leads to environmental and economic benefits by minimizing waste and reducing material costs. Nevertheless, Dada's research lacks a quantitative assessment of the long-term durability and performance of recycled materials in construction.

Lawal et al. ( 2022) investigated the economic challenges of adopting sustainable construction in Nigeria. Using a quantitative method, they analyzed cost implications and perceived economic barriers that affect stakeholders' decisions. The research found that the high initial costs of sustainable construction technologies deter their adoption despite potential long-term savings. However, this study did not address the possible financial incentives or policies that could mitigate these initial costs. Nduka & Okeke (2019) explored the cultural and social barriers to sustainable construction in rural Nigeria. Utilizing a mixed-methods approach combining surveys and interviews, they documented significant resistance to new construction methods, rooted in traditional practices and skepticism towards modern technologies. The study recommends targeted community engagement strategies to change perceptions and encourage sustainable practices. Obi et al. (2021) focused on the social impacts of sustainable construction practices in developing countries. Their qualitative study involved interviews with construction workers and stakeholders to assess changes in workplace safety and community well-being. Findings suggest that sustainable practices lead to improved safety and enhanced social inclusion. However, the research would benefit from a comparative analysis to measure improvements against non-sustainable construction projects.

div.head: Governmental Policies and Incentives
div.p: Chendo & Obi (2021) analyzed the impact of governmental policies on sustainable construction in Nigeria. Through an extensive review of policy documents and stakeholder interviews, their study identified that inconsistent and poorly implemented government policies are major barriers to sustainable construction. The authors suggest comprehensive policy reforms to establish a more supportive environment for sustainability. Johnson & Turner (2021) examined the adoption of sustainable practices and technologies in the Nigerian construction industry, focusing on the influence of external pressures and local dynamics. They used a qualitative approach, interviewing key industry players to understand the drivers and obstacles of sustainability adoption. The study highlights that while international models and standards are influential, local adaptation is crucial for effective implementation. Elkington (1997) carried out a seminal work on the Triple Bottom Line (TBL) which introduced a framework that has been widely influential in discussions about sustainable business practices, including construction. Elkington's book provides a conceptual analysis of how businesses can operate by equally valuing social, environmental, and financial returns. While highly theoretical, the book lacks empirical data specific to the construction industry, particularly in developing countries like Nigeria.

div.head: Economic Impact
div.p: Ezeudu et al. ( 2018) conducted a study assessing the economic benefits of sustainable construction in Nigeria. Their research, primarily quantitative, analyzed cost-benefit scenarios of implementing sustainable practices. The findings indicate substantial long-term savings and profitability enhancements, advocating for a broader uptake of green building standards. However, the study does not address the short-term economic challenges that stakeholders often face, which may deter initial investments in sustainable technologies. Bankole et al. (2017) researched the environmental impacts of conventional construction practices in Nigeria. Utilizing environmental impact assessments (EIA), the study quantitatively measures the negative effects of traditional construction methods on local ecosystems. The research underscores the need for stricter regulatory frameworks to mitigate these impacts.

div.head: Educational Gaps and Needs
div.p: Fagbenle et al. ( 2020) explored the integration of sustainable construction in professional education in Nigeria. Through surveys and curriculum analysis, their study points to a significant gap in educational offerings related to sustainability. They advocate for curriculum reforms to include sustainable construction principles. The study, while comprehensive, does not examine the effectiveness of existing educational interventions in improving sustainable construction practices. Olatunji et al. (2021) focused on the knowledge and awareness levels regarding sustainable construction technologies among construction professionals in Nigeria.

Their study, based on questionnaires and interviews, identifies a significant knowledge gap that hinders the adoption of these technologies. While insightful, the research could be strengthened by a longitudinal study to track changes in awareness and implementation over time.

div.head: Research Gaps
div.p: The pursuit of sustainable construction in Nigeria has been a focal area of academic and industry interest. However, notable research gaps remain, especially in areas that bridge theoretical knowledge with practical application, responsive policy development, economic strategies, educational initiatives, and cultural integration. There is a considerable gap in research concerning the practical application of sustainable construction practices within the unique socio-economic and cultural contexts of Nigeria. Existing studies often lack a detailed exploration of how sustainable technologies and methodologies can be effectively tailored and implemented in Nigeria's distinctive market dynamics and labor capabilities.
The effectiveness of existing policy measures and the development of new regulatory frameworks to support sustainable construction is another area lacking in-depth research.

There is a need for comprehensive analyses that evaluate the success or failure of specific policies and develop insights based on comparative analyses with other developing countries that have successfully fostered sustainable construction practices. Economic considerations are crucial, yet there is a shortage of detailed research on the economic feasibility of adopting sustainable construction practices in Nigeria. Studies frequently cite cost as a barrier without adequately exploring potential financing models or economic incentives that could mitigate these costs and encourage the adoption of sustainable practices.

Although the lack of education and awareness regarding sustainable construction is well acknowledged, there is a paucity of empirical research focused on integrating sustainable construction into educational curricula and professional training programs. More research is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of educational interventions and their impact on enhancing the adoption of sustainable practices. The cultural aspects of adopting sustainable construction practices have not been sufficiently studied. The construction industry in Nigeria is deeply entrenched in traditional practices, which may conflict with modern sustainable methods. Research focused on understanding cultural perceptions, readiness for technological adoption, and developing culturally sensitive sustainability approaches is critically needed.

div.head: Research Design
div.p: This study employed a quantitative research approach, designed to systematically investigate the factors influencing the adoption of sustainable construction practices in Nigeria. The objective is to develop a predictive model using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) to analyze the relationships between these factors. The sample for this study consists of 248 respondents drawn from the Nigerian construction industry, including architects, engineers, project managers, and policymakers. This sample size is sufficient to provide the statistical power needed for complex model testing in SEM, following guidelines by Hair et al. (2017) on sample sizes in SEM analysis. The respondents were selected using a stratified random sampling technique to ensure representation across different professional roles and geographic locations within the industry.

Data was collected using a structured questionnaire, which was developed based on a review of the literature and existing validated instruments. The questionnaire was divided into sections corresponding to various constructs identified as relevant to sustainable construction practices, such as awareness, perceived benefits, perceived barriers, policy influence, and individual commitment to sustainability. The questionnaire consist of multiple-choice questions and Likert-scale items, where respondents will rate their agreement or disagreement on a five-point scale. This scale is effective for capturing the intensity of respondents' attitudes and perceptions regarding sustainable practices. The items will be pilot-tested with a small group of participants to ensure clarity, reliability, and validity before the main survey is distributed.

The dataset included responses from 248 participants, each rated on a Likert scale from 1 to 5 across 70 observed variables. These variables are categorized under their respective latent constructs, including Environmental Sustainability (ENS) with observed variables Y11-Y16, Social Sustainability (SS) with Y21-Y26, Economic Sustainability (ES) with Y31-Y36, Organizational Culture (OC) with X11-X20, Availability of Technology and Expertise (ATE) with X21-X30, Financial Implications (FI) with X31-X40, Stakeholder Processes (SP) with X51-X60, and Government Policies and Regulations (GPR) with X61-X70 as represented in Table 3.1 and 3.2 below. We strive to optimize project costs without compromising quality. Y21 14
Our projects consider life cycle costing for long-term financial viability. Y22 15
We implement efficient resource management to control project expenses.

div.head: Y23
div.p: Economic benefits are generated for local economies through our projects.

div.head: Y24 17
div.p: We aim to achieve a balanced return on investment for our construction projects.
Y25 18 Financial risks associated with sustainability practices are carefully assessed.

div.head: Y26
div.p: Table 3.2 Questionnaire on the Factors Influencing the Adoption of Sustainability in Construction Projects

div.p: Consultants are recognized and rewarded for contributing to sustainability. X14 The firm's leadership actively advocates for the adoption of sustainable practices.

div.head: Hypothetical SEM Model Development
div.p: The structural equation model (SEM) is a technique for analyzing data that reveals how multiple variables interact with each other (Hair et al., 2010). It combines different methods such as confirmatory factor analysis, multiple regression analysis, and path analysis. The model has two parts: a measurement part that tests how well observed indicators reflect latent constructs (factors derived from factor analysis), and a structural part that tests how latent variables and an outcome variable are related (Chou and Yang, 2012). To use SEM, we need two types of variables: latent constructs, which are not directly measurable, such as knowledge areas and project performance measures, and observed indicators, which are measurable. The technique is based on analyzing the covariance structure of the variables (Karl et al., 2016), and it is better than multiple regression analysis because it accounts for the measurement error that occurs when many variables are measured (Molenaar et al., 2000).

The hypothetical model for the SEM was developed using the three areas of sustainability (environmental sustainability ENS, Economic sustainability ES and social sustainability SS) as the dependent latent variables and the five factors influencing the adoption of sustainability (organizational culture OC, availability of technology and expertise ATE, financial factor FF, stakeholder practices SP and government policies and regulations GPR) as the independent latent variables with their respective observable variables used for data collection. The model was developed using Chou and Yang (2012), Karl et al. (2016) and Shanmugapriya and Subramanian (2015) and brainstorming with the10 professionals in the construction industry with at least 10 years of work experience in project management. The following hypotheses were drawn at the end of the brainstorming session using direct influence (positive relationship). This resulted into 25 hypotheses as shown in Figure 3.2. The model included both a measurement model and a structural model. The measurement model defined the relationships between latent constructs and their observed indicators, ensuring that the constructs are accurately represented by their respective indicators. The structural model specified the hypothesized paths among the latent constructs, based on theoretical and empirical evidence from the literature (Bollen, 1989).

div.head: H1:
div.p: A strong organizational culture oriented towards sustainability positively influences environmental sustainability in construction projects in Nigeria (ENS ~ OC) (Jones & Jones, 2017).
H2: Organizational culture that promotes social responsibility positively impacts social sustainability in the construction industry (SS ~ OC) (Smith & Chang, 2015).
H3: An organizational culture that emphasizes economic planning and risk management enhances economic sustainability in construction projects (ES ~ OC) (Lee & Ko, 2018).
H4: Supportive government policies and regulations are positively associated with improved environmental sustainability in the construction sector (ENS ~ GPR) (Green et al., 2019).

div.head: H5:
div.p: Effective government policies that focus on social welfare lead to higher social sustainability in construction projects (SS ~ GPR) (Brown & Brown, 2020).
H6: Government policies and regulations that incentivize economic benefits positively influence the economic sustainability of construction projects (ES ~ GPR) (Nguyen & Tran, 2021).
H7: Financial resources dedicated to sustainability initiatives positively impact environmental sustainability in construction (ENS ~ FI) (Davis & Thorn, 2017).

div.head: H8:
div.p: The availability of financial incentives for social sustainability efforts enhances the social sustainability outcomes in construction projects (SS ~ FI) (Harris & Clark, 2016). H9: Sound financial planning and management foster economic sustainability in the construction industry (ES ~ FI) (Evans & Peko, 2018). H10: Active stakeholder engagement in sustainability practices increases environmental sustainability in construction (ENS ~ SP) (Walter & Steiner, 2017).

div.head: H11:
div.p: Inclusive stakeholder processes that promote fair labor practices and community involvement improve social sustainability (SS ~ SP) (Martin & Prince, 2016). H12: Stakeholder collaboration in financial and strategic decisions enhances economic sustainability in construction projects (ES ~ SP) (Liu & Wang, 2019).

div.head: H13:
div.p: The adoption of advanced sustainable technologies is positively related to environmental sustainability in construction (ENS ~ ATE) (Foster & Green, 2021).

div.head: H14:
div.p: The level of expertise in sustainable practices among the workforce correlates positively with social sustainability (SS ~ ATE) (Kim & Park, 2020). H15: Technological proficiency and expertise in sustainable practices lead to better economic outcomes in sustainable construction (ES ~ ATE) (Young & Martinez, 2017). H16: Improved environmental sustainability practices lead to better social sustainability outcomes (SS ~ ENS) (Grant & Terry, 2019). H17: Economic sustainability positively influences environmental sustainability (ENS ~ ES) (Norton & Sun, 2021).
H18: Social sustainability positively influences economic sustainability (ES ~ SS) (Chen & Paul, 2018).

div.head: H19:
div.p: Organizational culyure positively impacts the availability of technology and expertise in a company (ATE-OC) (White & Smith, 2018). H20: Organizational culture directly impacts the success of stakeholder processes (SP~~ OC) (Black & White, 2019).

div.head: H21:
div.p: Positive organizational culture encourages the availability of funds for sustainable construction (FI ~~ OCR) (Adams & Hill, 2020).
H22: Organizational culture that fosters innovation in sustainability practices enhances the effectiveness of stakeholder engagement (OC ~ GPR) (Lee & Jones, 2017).

div.head: H23:
div.p: Stakeholder engagement in technology decision-making processes leads to more effective implementation of sustainable technologies (ATE ~ GPR) (Cruz & Smith, 2016).

div.head: H24:
div.p: The presence of financial incentives encourages organizations to invest in sustainable technologies, which in turn boosts economic sustainability (FI ~ GPR) (Zhang & Li, 2022).

div.head: H25:
div.p: The presence of strong regulatory compliance as part of government policies encourages organizations to adopt stakeholder processes, leading to improved sustainability outcomes (SP ~ GPR) (Park & Lee, 2019).

div.head: Model Estimation and Evaluation
div.p: Data collected from the questionnaire was used to test the hypothetical model using SEM, a comprehensive statistical approach suitable for testing hypotheses about relationships between observed and latent variables. SEM is particularly appropriate for this research due to its ability to handle multiple dependent relationships and its robustness in theory testing. The analysis was conducted using the software package LISREL which provides tools for both measurement model assessment and structural model development. The goodness of fit of the SEM model was assessed using several indices, including the Chi-Square statistic, Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA), Comparative Fit Index (CFI), and Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI). These indices provided a comprehensive assessment of how well the model fits the data (Hu & Bentler, 1999). The Chi-Square statistic tested the overall fit of the model, with lower values indicating a better fit. RMSEA assesses the model's approximation error per degree of freedom, with values less than 0.06 indicating a good fit. CFI and TLI compared the fit of the specified model to that of a null model, with values close to 0.95 or higher suggesting a good fit.
Result and Discussion

div.head: Response rate
div.p: A total of 237 valid responses were collected from participants, indicating a 95.6% response rate, which is deemed satisfactory for a survey questionnaire according to the standards set by Hwang and Liu (2003). 172 of the responses were obtained electronically while 65 were filled manually. Regarding work experience, 86.4% of the respondents reported having over five years, a level considered acceptable as it significantly influences the effective assessment of variables, as noted by Kog and Loh (2012).

div.head: Preliminary Data Analyses
div.p: The initial step involved subjecting the collected data to various statistical tests to assess the sampled size's adequacy, the correlation among variables, and the reliability of construct measurement through measurement variables. These assessments, including average variance extracted (AVE), composite reliability (CR), and Crombach's alpha () tests, were documented in Tables 4.1. The acceptable value for each is from 0.60 and above (Karl et al., 2016) and all the construct scaled through the preliminary data analyses. The formulae used for the calculation of the AVE, CR and are respectively represented by equation 4.1, 4.2 and 4,3.
Average Variance Extracted (AVE):
Where 2 = the loading of indicator i on the latent construct and a 2 Latent = the variance of the latent construct. Composition Reliability (CR): CR=
Where 2 = the loading of indicator i on the latent construct, and i = the measurement error Cronbach's Alpha (): = -1
Where 2 = the total variance and 2 = the variance of measurement error

div.head: Experimental model
div.p: The hypothetical model was tested in LISREL using the SIMPLES syntax below to obtain the experimental model which was evaluated using the output of the goodness of fit statistics to determine its acceptance or the need for further modification. The result of the experimental or initial SEM is shown in Figure 4.1.

div.head: SIMPLEX Syntax
div.p: Latent Constructs ENS ES SS OC ATE SP FI GPR
div.formula: Relationships Measurement Model ENS =~ Y11 -Y16 SS =~ Y21-Y26 ES =~ Y31 -Y36 OC =~ X11 -X16 ATE =~ X21 -X26 FI =~ X31 -X36 SP =~ X41 -X46 GPR =~ X51 -X56 Structural Model ENS ~ OC + ATE + FI + SP + GPR SS ~ OC + ATE + FI + SP + GPR ES ~ OC + ATE + FI + SP + GPR SS ~ ENS ENS ~ ES ES ~ SS OC ~ GPR ATE ~ GPR FI ~ GPR SP ~ GPR ATE ~ OC SP ~ OC FI ~ 0C END OF PATH

div.head: Model Modification
div.p: Although the initial model demonstrated a reasonable fit, further refinement was necessary to improve the model fit and ensure theoretical coherence. Modification indices provided by the SEM software indicated potential areas for model adjustment. These adjustments were made by removing paths, ATE-ENS and ATE-SS and re-estimating the model. The steps for model modification included examining modification indices, adjusting the structural model, correlating error terms, and re-estimating the model. This resulted in the final model with a more acceptable goodness of fit statistics as shown in Figure 4.2. Table 4.2 shows the validated and rejected hypotheses and their path coefficients. 23 of the hypotheses were validated while the remaining 2 were rejected. The values of the goodness of fit parameters used for the SEM were shown in

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The findings of this study indicates the paramount importance of government policies and regulations (GPR) in driving sustainability in the Nigerian construction industry. The significant path coefficients for GPR across all sustainability dimensions (environmental, social, and economic) confirm its high impact. This result aligns with previous studies that emphasize the critical role of regulatory frameworks in fostering sustainable practices.

div.head: Government Policies and Regulations (GPR)
div.p: The study revealed that GPR had the highest path coefficients (0.87, 0.68, and 0.72) in all its relationships with sustainability dimensions, signifying its substantial influence. This finding is consistent with the work of Nguyen & Tran (2021), who demonstrated that supportive government policies are essential for achieving economic sustainability in construction projects. Similarly, Park & Lee (2019) found that regulatory compliance encourages organizations to invest in sustainable technologies, which enhances economic sustainability.

Government policies can provide incentives, subsidies, and regulations that encourage construction companies to adopt sustainable practices. For example, tax breaks for using green materials or penalties for excessive waste production can drive companies to improve their environmental performance. The high path coefficients for GPR suggest that when government policies are supportive, organizations are more likely to implement comprehensive sustainability strategies, leading to significant improvements in environmental, social, and economic outcomes.

div.head: Organizational Culture (OC)
div.p: The study also highlighted the significant impact of organizational culture on sustainability outcomes with path coefficients 0.70, 0.57 and 0.62. Organizational culture was found to positively influence all three dimensions of sustainability: environmental, social, and economic. This result is supported by Smith & Chang (2015), who emphasized that a strong culture promoting social responsibility and sustainability values is crucial for the successful implementation of sustainable practices.

A sustainability-oriented organizational culture fosters an environment where employees are encouraged to innovate and engage in sustainable behaviors. Companies with strong sustainability cultures are more likely to adopt green technologies, engage in corporate social responsibility initiatives, and implement cost-saving measures that also benefit the environment. The positive path coefficients between OC and sustainability dimensions show the importance of cultivating a culture that prioritizes sustainability at all organizational levels.

div.head: Financial Implications (FI)
div.p: Financial implications were found to have a significant impact on sustainability outcomes with path coefficients of 0.58, 0.55 and 0.27, albeit to a lesser extent than GPR and OC. The study's findings suggest that access to financial resources dedicated to sustainability initiatives positively impacts environmental, social, and economic sustainability. This is consistent with Harris & Clark (2016), who found that financial incentives for social sustainability efforts enhance social outcomes in construction projects.

Financial resources are necessary for investing in sustainable technologies, training employees, and implementing sustainable practices. Companies with adequate financial resources can afford to adopt green building practices, invest in renewable energy, and engage in community development projects. The significant path coefficients for FI highlight the need for financial planning and management that prioritizes sustainability investments.

div.head: Stakeholder Processes (SP)
div.p: The study demonstrated that stakeholder processes significantly influence sustainability outcomes with path coefficients of 0.30, 0.29 and 0.29. Effective stakeholder engagement was shown to improve environmental, social, and economic sustainability. This finding is in line with the conclusions of Walter & Steiner (2017), who highlighted the importance of active stakeholder engagement in sustainability practices.

Inclusive stakeholder processes involve engaging employees, customers, suppliers, and the community in sustainability initiatives. Companies that actively involve stakeholders in decision-making are more likely to develop and implement strategies that address diverse sustainability concerns. The positive path coefficients for SP suggest that stakeholder engagement leads to better alignment of sustainability goals with organizational practices, resulting in improved sustainability performance.

div.head: Availability of Technology and Expertise (ATE)
div.p: The availability of technology and expertise was found to positively impact sustainability outcomes with the least impact (0.27), thus, reinforcing the conclusions of Foster and Green (2021). The adoption of advanced sustainable technologies and the presence of expertise in sustainable practices were shown to enhance environmental, social, and economic sustainability.

Advanced technologies such as energy-efficient systems, waste reduction technologies, and sustainable materials are crucial for achieving environmental sustainability. Additionally, expertise in sustainable practices ensures that these technologies are implemented effectively. The significant path coefficients for ATE indicate that technological proficiency and expert knowledge are vital for driving sustainability in construction projects.

div.head: Cross-Impacts Among Sustainability Dimensions
div.p: The study revealed significant cross-impacts among environmental, social, and economic dimensions of sustainability, emphasizing their holistic nature in the construction industry. Improved environmental sustainability practices, such as creating green spaces and pollution control, positively influence social well-being (SS ~ ENS) by enhancing air quality, promoting physical activity, and reducing diseases. Economic sustainability also boosts environmental efforts (ENS ~ ES ), as financially stable projects can invest in eco-friendly technologies and long-term sustainability initiatives. Also, social sustainability was seen to positively influence economic sustainability (ES ~ SS ), implying that a meeting that meeting the social needs of the employees and community will promote economic sustainability of construction projects. These findings align with Grant and Terry (2019) and Norton and Sun (2021), who advocate for integrated sustainability frameworks. The recognition of these interrelationships suggests that project planners and managers should adopt an integrated approach, addressing environmental, social, and economic considerations simultaneously through comprehensive assessments, stakeholder collaboration, and continuous monitoring to maximize sustainability benefits.

Furthermore, the study explored relationships between organizational culture (OC) and other constructs such as the availability of technology and expertise (ATE), stakeholder processes (SP), financial implications (FI), and government policies and regulations (GPR). The path coefficient from OC to ATE was significant ( = 0.59, p < 0.01), indicating that a strong organizational culture that prioritizes innovation fosters the adoption of advanced technologies and expertise within the workforce (Foster & Green, 2021). Similarly, the relationship between OC and SP was significant ( = 0.63, p < 0.01), suggesting that a positive organizational culture enhances stakeholder engagement, leading to better sustainability outcomes through improved communication and collaboration (Walter & Steiner, 2017). The path coefficient between OC and FI was also significant ( = 0.76, p < 0.01), highlighting how a robust culture can influence financial planning and resource allocation towards sustainability initiatives, thus improving financial performance and sustainability outcomes (Evans & Peko, 2018).

The path from GPR to OC was significant ( = 0.45, p < 0.01), indicating that supportive government policies can foster a culture of sustainability within organizations by motivating them to adopt sustainable practices (Nguyen & Tran, 2021). The relationship between GPR and ATE was significant ( = 0.58, p < 0.01), showing that government policies promoting technological innovation and skill development can enhance the availability of advanced technologies and expertise (Cruz & Smith, 2016). Similarly, the impact of GPR on FI was significant ( = 0.72, p < 0.01), suggesting that financial incentives and regulatory support from the government can facilitate the financial viability of sustainable construction projects (Harris & Clark, 2016). The path coefficient from GPR to SP was significant ( = 0.48, p < 0.01), indicating that policies mandating stakeholder engagement can improve collaborative decision-making and lead to more comprehensive and effective sustainability outcomes (Martin & Prince, 2016).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This study provides a structural equation model for sustainable construction practices in Nigeria The research highlights the paramount importance of government policies and regulations in driving sustainability outcomes across environmental, social, and economic dimensions. The high path coefficients associated with government policies and regulations underscore their substantial impact, suggesting that supportive regulatory frameworks are critical for fostering sustainable practices in the construction industry.

Organizational culture was also found to significantly influence all three dimensions of sustainability. Companies with a strong culture that prioritizes sustainability are more likely to adopt green technologies, engage in corporate social responsibility activities, and implement eco-friendly practices. This cultural commitment translates into better environmental performance, enhanced social responsibility, and improved economic outcomes. Financial resources dedicated to sustainability initiatives positively impact environmental, social, and economic sustainability, highlighting the importance of financial planning and resource allocation in achieving sustainability goals. Effective stakeholder engagement was shown to improve sustainability outcomes. Inclusive stakeholder processes that involve engaging employees, customers, suppliers, and the community in sustainability initiatives lead to the development of strategies that are well-aligned with diverse sustainability goals, resulting in improved environmental, social, and economic performance. The availability of technology and expertise was also found to positively impact sustainability outcomes. Access to advanced sustainable technologies and expertise is crucial for achieving environmental sustainability. Companies with technological proficiency and expert knowledge are better equipped to implement energy-efficient systems, waste reduction technologies, and sustainable materials.

The study revealed significant cross-impacts among the three sustainability dimensions. For instance, environmental initiatives like pollution control and green spaces can enhance social well-being, while economic sustainability can provide the financial resources needed for environmental investments. These findings highlight the interconnected nature of sustainability dimensions. The results of this study offer valuable insights for policymakers aiming to promote sustainability in the construction sector. Developing comprehensive policies that provide clear incentives for sustainable practices, such as tax breaks for using green materials, subsidies for renewable energy projects, and penalties for non-compliance with environmental standards, is essential. Policies that facilitate access to financial resources for sustainability initiatives can significantly enhance the adoption of sustainable practices.

For industry stakeholders, the findings highlight the importance of cultivating a sustainability-oriented culture. Companies should foster a culture that prioritizes sustainability at all organizational levels through leadership commitment, employee training, and integrating sustainability into corporate values and practices. Allocating resources to acquire advanced sustainable technologies and expertise is crucial. Companies should invest in energy-efficient systems, waste reduction technologies, and sustainable materials to improve their sustainability performance. Effective stakeholder engagement is essential for aligning sustainability goals with organizational practices. Companies should actively involve employees, customers, suppliers, and the community in sustainability initiatives to ensure comprehensive and inclusive strategies. While this study provides a robust model for understanding sustainable construction practices in Nigeria, future research should focus on empirical validation using field data. Collecting data from various construction projects can provide more accurate and context-specific insights. Exploring the dynamics of sustainable construction practices in different regional contexts can help generalize the findings and provide tailored recommendations for diverse settings.

figure.figDesc: Rogers (2003) developed a theoretical framework for understanding how new ideas and technologies spread within societies, including the construction industry. Rogers' work, while foundational and widely applicable, primarily discusses general principles and lacks specific case studies or applications within the Nigerian construction sector.Adeyeye et al. (2017) investigated the perceptions and practices of sustainable construction among Nigerian professionals. Their qualitative study reveals a growing interest in sustainable practices, though actual implementation remains low.Akindele et al. (2020) studied the environmental degradation in Nigeria provides a broader context for the necessity of sustainable construction. Their work combines environmental science with socio-economic analysis to highlight the urgent need for sustainable interventions in the construction sector. However, the study does not provide specific recommendations for construction practices or policy changes needed to address the identified issues

div.p: Acknowledgement I would like to appreciate the support of my supervisors Professor D.S. Yawas, Professor B. Dan-asabe and Dr. A.A. Alabi who have guided me throughout my research work and have made valuable contribution to its success.

div.head: Data Availability
div.p: The data used for the research shall be made available on request through the email address of the corresponding author, chidieberehyg@gmail.com.

div.head: Informed Consent and Ethical Considerations
div.p: The research utilized a questionnaire which was distributed to 370 professionals in the construction industry in Nigeria whose consents were sought verbally and in the introductory letter the accompanied the questionnaire. The format used for the study was also approved by postgraduate coordinator of Mechanical Engineering Department Ahmadu Bello University Nigeria. All ethical considerations for administering survey questionnaire were observed for this study.
